column1: Before 7 May 2021, will the Bank of England set its Bank Rate to below zero?
column6: ['Business', 'Finance', 'Economic Policy']
Crowd
6 days? I don’t think so...
Highly unlikely given that BOE never even set the Bank Rate at zero.
Bank of England opposed to 0 or below interest rates.

Labour markets are improving, job losses compared to pre-pandemic era are huge, but job creation has begun. Brexit impact on the economy (fallout on cost, exports etc.) starts to show, but will likely not matter for the BoE with respect to risks associated to negative interest rates. Unemployment as a 3-month trailing rate will likely remain at 4.7% to 5.1% for the remainder of this question, as the figure has significant inertia, and thus, on a historically (since 1971) acceptable level, unemployment will not trigger any negative interest rates.
Dropping on time, financial market performance, and lack of indications from MPC this is on the cards in the short term.
Negative interest rates mean borrowing is cheaper than anything else. Banks make no money, and individuals take out copious quantities of debt. It's stupid. BOE is too smart to think it a good idea.
A zero or negative rate will impact government supporters significantly, despite the poor current rate it can be defended and offers something to savers.
0.1% record low right now, so a small chance, but improving economic outlook.

The Monetary Policy Committee voted unanimously to keep its main lending rate at 0.1% and maintain its target stock of asset purchases at £895 billion ($1.2 trillion). ... It comes after the BOE cut rates twice following the onset of the pandemic from 0.75%, and deployed an unprecedented quantitative easing program.

I'd put zero but don't really want to do that for something that is per se generally within the bounds of the plausible. Think it is reasonable that vaccination will be a success and that a rebound will still be predicted for this year. That is however an element of wishcasting on my part as obviously I want the vaccination programme to be a success, but also because I think interest rates are far too low already.
Time update
They will need to equalize EU

No change for now on my forecast and apparently no change from BoE too - https://bloom.bg/3cLij7z. It seems the Gilt rate creep in UK and bond creep elsewhere has not concerned the BoE. The unanimity of the MPC seems clear about the current course of action - https://bit.ly/3vGdYuS. As the next MPC is 6 May and IMHO there's little likelihood of change in between now and then, as the BoE appears to be hesitant to not move too early on the upside as that may choke off any signs of a recovery, I will retain my forecast. Maintaining the current rate and asset purchases does leave the BoE some room to manoeuvre should the need arise. The flip side, and what the MPC seems to be thinking is that there's likely to be a relatively strong rebound in spending resulting from the vaccination program, the governments support program and the announced schedule for the easing of the lock down / restrictions. There is increasing talk that 'pent up spending' in UK and USA will contribute significantly to this rebound. That may contribute to the BoE's 2% inflation target. However, the BoE is also cognisant of the unemployment rate.
https://www.theguardian.com/business/live/2021/mar/18/bank-of-england-federal-reserve-markets-ftse-pound-eurozone-us-jobless-business-live
@SE_Meyer & @sevedb
Rising long-term interest rates and expectation for inflation.
No commentary from BOE suggests this will happen even this year ... the pros and cons of negative rates are being discussed also and the pendulum is swinging against at the moment.
Getting less likely by the day I think as an end to the pandemic slowly approaches. Moving to 0%.
It's below 0 in real terms now. Why go even further.?
QE yes. Negative rates not for a while. the struggle will be more for them to hold interest rates down with raising inflation, not to try to stimulate the economy in general.

The MPC has maintained the bank rate at 0.1% in its Feb 2021 meeting amidst an inflationary target of 2%, increasing GDP outlook over 2021 and CPI at 0.6%. All these factors remain favorable to continue the same stance in the next meeting due 18 March 2021. Hence, the bank rate will not fall below zero, unless any of the above-mentioned factors change significantly in Q1.

Jumping on this one late which should hopefully turn out well for me here. The precedence for below 0 Bank Rates is low. Many western economists see any positives of a negative cash rate being far outweighed by the negatives. Recent indicators in the US, as well as in bond markets indicate that in fact we may see the reverse happening in the future (but not likely before 1 May). In short, I don't see this happening, especially in the timeframe given and with global economic recovery looking stronger than predicted.
Dropping on recent commentary, speed of vaccination and the assumption that today’s rally ends the financial market volatility
Trimming to 0%. Steepening of yield curves, rise in inflation expectations, latest UK roadmap dating June for the full unlocking of the economy.
I do not see this happening before May based on current BoE statements and inference.
Brexit.

Of course nothing is every truly 0% but the one thing a central bank cares about more than anything is that people believe them when they say stuff. If they say prepare for this possibility 6 months from now they will not do it prior to that unless truly it was somehow the only option available in an epic crisis, which is hard to imagine.
Below-zero interest rates are reportedly a topic among the BoE board, but for "late 2021" or even 2022, and it will crucially depend on the future development of British unemployment rates.
Reducing estimate due to passage of time and the time period banks need to prepare if negative interest rates.
Just updating over time. Still no sign that this will happen. Even if something significant happens, it will take a bit of time to reset the rates.
The base rate is already extremely low due to COVID. So the only way this happens is if something else, as bad or worse, coincides with a 3rd (4th?) wave. Very low odds if you ask me.
Overshot based on 0% forecast prior. The United Kingdom wants to be a part of Hong Kong. If they are not maybe I should change my forecast higher and buy an underground nuclear shelter.
Seems like a low possibility especially since Brexit is has just been introduced and a negative interest rate would be seen in the UK as them following EU
Looking very unlikely now, given economy likely to bounce post-vaccine
Passage of time and vaccine rollout. Only two meetings left, with no real heads-up so far.
Passage of time

Lowering the odds further to take account of the speedy vaccine rollout underway in the UK which is likely to spur economic recovery in 2Q. Speculation on Chancellor Rushi Sunak's March budget points to fiscal tools as the preferred demand management tool. So, all in, unlikely to see negative interest rates from the BOE which has historically differed from the ECB & Japan in putting more weight on the medium term, unintended negative consequences on banks and savers.

BoE announced warning to prepare for possibility of negative interest rates in next 6 months. This news is likely to be more of a timeline of when banking systems will be ready to cope with negative rates.

Independent or not this would be a political decision impacting on millions of the government's voters so the Treasury would intervene before it was able to happen as polling would indicate the damage it will do.

The Bank of England (BoE) is scheduled to announce its monetary policy decision at 12:00 GMT this Thursday. The UK central bank is widely anticipated to keep its policy settings unchanged, i.e. leave the benchmark interest rate and the size of the Asset Purchase Facility unchanged at 0.10% and £895 billion, respectively. The only thing the market will care about is the likelihood of negative interest rates.
Recent hawkish commentary
Based on the bullish outlook of the BOE, and their commitment to the current policy of buying bonds I don’t see a rate change below 0.
[Quote]
@SE_Meyer & @sevedb
Raising in light of today's comments
The latest BOE statement from 4 Feb rejects negative rates and is bullish on the UK economy.
Today's bank minutes effectively ruled it out for operational reasons within the next 6 months. Keeping some residual for "unknowns"

MPC fairly bullish on inflation in this month's report, expecting a tick up throughout this year. https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/-/media/boe/files/monetary-policy-report/2021/february/monetary-policy-report-february-2021.pdf?la=en&hash=3638A7091B34164428A54277B55BD6901709AA44
The economy should start recovering from the pandemic due to the vaccinations in the UK. So no need for the BOE to cut rates more. They are also reluctant to do it.

The largest factor affecting the UK economy over the next few months is the rate of vaccinations, and how fast the economy recovers as it reopens. The BoE won't want to cut rates further into what looks like a strong upturn (judging by the level of cash savings and the amount of pent-up demand). I think tail risks are unlikely over such a short period. The risk of different strains of Covid is real, but so far all the new variants have responded relatively well to the vaccines (ie not vaccine-resistant), so it seems unlikely that a vaccine-resistant strain emerges in the next 3 months when it hasn't done so far.
Unlikely, particularly in short time frame of question

Downgrading slightly based on the noises coming from BoE, particularly concerns about UK commercial banks kicking up a stink https://www.investing.com/news/economy/any-yes-from-boe-on-negative-rates-is-likely-to-be-cautious-2403265
The fallout from Brexit is still being worked out, but by May, the Bank will set its rate below 0 for a momentary pause
Not unless they start smoking crack.

Given the minimal effects and potential adverse impact on banking profitability, my guess is they would pursue more QE or maybe lower rates to zero. They don’t have much of an asset bubble in the equity market and inflation is at a reasonable level so I don’t see why they wouldn’t continue with QE. Negative rates also have the potential to “spook” the market with only marginal economic benefits in terms of increased borrowing.
My guess is that the way to negative rates is that they'd go to 0% on 4 Feb, then let that play out for more than 3 months.
Doing so would be an admission things are going badly. May is too soon for that.
While to goal is to stimulate economic growth, it would still be challenging to justify an interest rate below zero.

Questions: Q1 is the bank set up for negative rates? Q2 results on GDP growth vs Eurozone Q3 Sucess of COVID vaccination strategy Q4 Sunak budget and plan to bring down the deficit Q5 unemployment rate Q1 Q6 monetary committee members leaning

Base rate has been at 0.1 since March 2020. Some members of the Bank's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) have discussed the possibility of reducing to below zero, notably Michael Saunders in early December 2020. https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/-/media/boe/files/speech/2020/michael-saunder-some-monetary-policy-options-if-more-support-is-needed.pdf?la=en&hash=CBA72BE6376441756ABA4ACBF3218A0555927E7B. However the outlook for growth appears somewhat more optimistic now than then, due to the agreement of a UK-EU trade deal (however flawed, it is still better than No Deal which was in play until just before Christmas) and the UK's relatively smooth rollout of the Covid vaccine in January 2021. Meanwhile the Bank's governor Andrew Bailey has expressed caution about negative rates https://www.cityam.com/sterling-strengthens-after-bank-boss-andrew-bailey-dismisses-negative-rates-talk/. Assessing the MPC's previous decisions (https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/-/media/boe/files/monetary-policy-summary-and-minutes/mpcvoting.xlsx?la=en&hash=BD20B2AB676F5EB8FFBE568C8568C5A34FF4A742) I expect Bailey, not Saunders, is more representative of members' current thinking.

Looks like the UK are heading for a long, costly and damaging period of all-national lock down, the economic fall-out of which will be beyond all expectations. Raising to "more-likely-than-not" because in order to cover the cost without sovereign-debt crisis or major market disruptions, more "incentive" to buy long-term bonds (call it "financial suppression", if you like) will be necessary, as the UK's economy is entering unchartered territory in the 400 year history of the Bank of England.

Tripling due to mutation possibly leading to massive contraction and negative rates becoming a (hopefully temporary) response (although I think other unconventional policies are still much more likely to come first.)
Close to.
Reiterating forecast. Lots of noise in both directions, but I think not a big change in the probabilities
up 2% - https://www.ft.com/content/9700f85c-fa75-4584-bfc6-c4a58a251ae3
minus 2% for passage of time and Bailey voicing his concern about negative rates once again.

Brexit is now a reality and covid-19 case numbers are growing in almost every country. UK apparently being one of the worst affected by the 'new' mutation. That combination potentially makes the BoE job more difficult and thus more inclined to be pressured into a negative rate scenario. However, the BoE has again (see previous forecasts and links) voiced concerns about the impact of negative rates on the banking sector. See https://reut.rs/3slnbr5. In the current scenario the UK finds itself in, the banking sector is likely to come under quite a lot of pressure and hence BoE may be more reluctant to put the banks' balance sheets at risk.
Sticking with low probability. Latest macros known. BOE as reluctant as ever.

BoE unlikely to go negative before 7 May without further bad economic news, which i think depends on vaccine rollout not going smoothly --> restrictions needed for longer/delayed getting back to normal.

FCA just recently published a very discomforting assessment that a quarter (?; have to look up the exact figures +links later...) of all small / medium sized financial institutions it is supervising are possibly near collapse due to weak capitalization. I don't know /have to explore whether a Bank Rate below zero is an appropriate remedy economically, but it is one the few things they haven't tried yet; it thus may lower the threshold to try.

If for no other reason than I do not believe such a move would provide the desired economic boost. Availability of credit is not the issue. COVID is the primary driver of current soft economic conditions.
A very big step and unlikely to want to be first. Will probably try everything else first and vaccines will not be complete by this date
Credibility issue. They're not going to repeat earlier fiscal mistakes, selling gold for nothing in the "Brown's bottom" https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sale_of_UK_gold_reserves,_1999%E2%80%932002
Covid cases are increasing and vaccines rollout is too slow. I think GDP numbers would be revised lower and monetary policy would need to be extra accommodative.

According to a Bank of England working paper, overnight indexed swap rates 'tend to accurately measure expectations of future short-term interest rates', with a conventional factor of 360 between overnight and annual rates (https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/working-paper/2018/overnight-index-swap-market-based-measures-of-monetary-policy-expectations). The nearest-neighbour linearly interpolated spot value of 7th May-maturity OIS rates on 29/12/20 was 0.03 (https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/statistics/yield-curves), so the market expectation seems to be that the Bank's base rate is 0.03/360 = 0.008%, with negative rates expected only in January 2022. But the 7th May expected rate seems to approximately follow an unbiased Gaussian random walk over time, with a typical 30-day change over the last 6 months of 0.010%. Supposing it matches the true rate at maturity, the implied probability of a negative rate is 35%.
Likely? No. But more than 5%? Definitely. I'll go for a third a take the odds the crowd is too status quo on this one.
Unconventional but always possible especially if further downturns.
A willing Chancellor and unwilling BOE Governor suggests expansionary fiscal policies rather than unorthodox monetary tools will be first port of call to spur growth and inflation.
More than likely to remain 0.1%
Trade will stall all growth in Q1

- potential economic "upswing" with vaccine deployment (UK at strong pace of vaccination) - downside of the "new variant" of COVID - will likely move parallel with US rate; improbable that they will go negative

The UK's banking system is old and complex - I used to work in tech in banking - and the complexity of handling negative or zero interest rates is so hard for the banks that the BoE will avoid it if at all possible.
Do not expect a substantial further weakening of growth prospects given Brexit deal and COVID efforts. Very unlikely to need further unconventional stimulus.
Correcting for typo
A bit above consensus, but think this is remote - used the data on here - https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/monetary-policy to come up with some base lines.
Just plain looks bad.
Putting it as highly unlikely (not impossible) but the prospect of having negative retail interest rates concerns many economist. Will people pay to store money at the bank, or trigger bank run?
With a Brexit deal done a new wave of economic disruptions will be avoided and I think the chances of negative interest rates is significantly reduced.
They'll probably crank up the QE programme rather than go negative. Full disclosure: They don't confide in me.

Reducing because the UK has just got a Brexit deal. The chance of no-deal Brexit is now significantly lower. This was one of the factors I considered and added 1 - 2% to my forecast for, which I will now remove.
The BoE has never set it's rate below 0 in the last 100 years (abt. 400 rates) => Base rate is 1%

BoE is stuck in an impossible position. Economy is likely to face downside uncertainties even with a smooth UK-EU trade deal. A rates below zero looks inevitable even though it has so far proved to be not effective in stimulate credit growth globally.
Nearing brexit deal.
Secret

Sounds like they've explored the option but don't intend to do it unless things get really bad. No deal brexit could be a factor in that, and I think a deal is looking pretty unlikely. But I think it's seen as a pretty extreme move, at least in the UK, so even with the economic problems associated with no deal Brexit I don't see it happening. And the vaccine rollout should help with coronavirus and a faster recovery.
Stimulate spending between covid recovery and brexit disaster.

Vlieghe, Tenreyro and Saunders have all recently made supportive comments for the use of negative rates, and Haskel has said the BOE is "open-minded" on the subject. The banking industry have also been told to prepare for it. Economically, you have brexit and the pandemic causing damage and finally, a lot of their major trading partners have negative rates, even though the debate about how much collateral damage they do rages on. So clearly the BOE both need, to and are willing, to consider negative rates. There does not seem to be any valid baseline to start from in terms of the economy as a brexit deal is a close call and the new pandemic strain (as well as the old one) are both still balanced by vaccine rollout so I will start at 3/9 - vocally semi-supportive voters on the MPC, but subtract 10% because the internal members and especially Bailey seem more opposed to it, and -5% as I think a brexit deal is more likely then not.
what i just said but i forget to change %
Andrew Bailey + current MCP is too conservative and it will not be a priority - he will continue with forward guidance and secondary market activity
Adjusted slightly up because of economic fallout risk from new CV strain
https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/monetary-policy-summary-and-minutes/2020/december-2020
It may seem counterintuitive to charge a business or consumer for depositing money, but that is what a negative rate does. It then allows a bank to lend at a negative rate, which rewards borrowers.

Chance of a Brexit-related problem Chance of worsening economy if current COVID wave longer/deeper than expected Unclear whether this could help if there's a crunch in commercial property lending/solvency but that's a midterm risk as well

The UK government appears to be pessimistic about a Brexit trade deal with the EU. See https://reut.rs/3mr4CgN . Nobody really knows what the implications of WTO rules between EU & UK will actually mean and what the consequent effects of that will be across numerous countries. What is likely is that the UK economy will weaken and take some time to adjust. Certainly well beyond the time frame of this question. Nonetheless, BoE must be very conscious of this possibility. At today's MPC meeting, the bank rate and QE were both left unchanged. In all likelihood, unless there is a serious crash in the economy, banking or financial sectors and an emergency MPC is called for, the BoE will only have two more meetings within the time frame of this question.

Increasing my previous position from 8 percent up to 10 percent. The Bank meeting today came with no change in the interest rate and a somewhat rosier outlook on the economic improvement in 2021. However, it appears one of the bedrocks of their economic assumption is a Brexit trade deal. This seems increasingly unlikely and thus increases the chances just slightly.
Highly doubtful, the BoE will rely on the government to continue forms of fiscal stimulus instead of a negative bank rate that may cause a run on the banks.
Slight chance if further shocks especially with regards to Covid or Brexit happen in early 2021.
Global economy is improving and vaccines are rolling out. No need to use risky new monetary policies at the moment.

Having already seen a sharp decline earlier in the year, I deem it unlikely to go any further south. Inflation remains muted however the added fiscal and monetary stimulus is likely to create inflationary pressure sometime in the future (albeit unlikely in the next year ill admit!). I predict the vaccine will be a success and will boost economic output during the year. Brexit concerns (especially in the case of a deal) may also put short term upward pressures on food prices. On the personality front, unless there is a further crisis e.g. vaccine unsuccesful/ newer Covid strain) we are unlikely to have Andrew Bailey shock the system and announce negative rates, especially just since October he announced "were not there yet on negative interest rates" https://www.cityam.com/bailey-says-bank-of-england-not-there-yet-on-negative-interest-rates/

The base rate set by the MPC of 0.1% is lower than it was in the aftermath of the financial crisis (0.5%). Mass production and use of a covid vaccine will be a major factor on how Britain & the global economy will recover. Inflation remained muted, 1.5% below BOE's target inflation of 2%. The MPC said they will take additional action if economy remains stagnant and inflation remains significantly below target. Four more meetings.

In their last update, the bank decided on 5 November to keep the base rate at 0.1%. Next, the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) decides the base rate. This committee meets to discuss it every 6 weeks to update the base rate.But due to the high drop from 0,75% in August 2018 to 0,1% on 19 March 2020 I assume they covered themselves for a longer period in the future, especially to potential unforeseen costs due to COVID.

The UK has been one of the European holdouts on moving toward a policy of negative interest rates. Although the monetary committee says a negative rate policy is still on the table, it appears to be increasingly unlikely they will move toward it. The rebounding UK, and global economy, in early 2021 would make it even more unlikely to have a negative rate. The outside chance of a negative rate is still possible due to a combination of economic stalling due to COVID-19 and the increasing likelihood of a no-deal Brexit. If the economy begins to struggle again in early '21 expect the discussion on negative rates to return.
after 7 may
The UK has never done this before and there will be significant pressure from media and backbenchers that this will result in the bank of England not engaging with this.
Poor financial management by the Govt and Treasury and poor leadership through the COVID-19 response

The pressure is on, and if it comes off it won't happen. The question is this: Will they crack before the vaccines are distributed and the economy rebounds (bringing the inflation rate back towards 2%)?

A couple of factors. To set the scene, this comment from Andrew Bailey, Governor, Bank of England, at the press conference after the last MPC meeting. (Pg 5 of https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/-/media/boe/files/monetary-policy-report/2020/november/mpr-press-conference-transcript-november-2020.pdf)

Unlikely now. Perhaps in January, after the Federal Reserve will announce its own monetary policy decision with analysts at Barclays Research anticipating that it will shift towards more qualitative guidance for continuing asset purchases - a reflection of the recently improved economic prospects.
The efficacy of the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines will prompt an economic rebound, or at least a rebound in confidence, that will prevent the BOE from taking this step.
It seems unlikely the BoE will take this option. However, a disastrous start to 2021 following a No-Deal Brexit could lead to a huge economic slump and a need for drastic action.
Wait until Brexit talks to adjust. Letter written to bank so they are prepping.
I know that several counties have a negative bank rate, but I don't see England doing it

Supporting negative rates https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/news-insights/latest-news-headlines/uk-banks-ready-for-painful-negative-interest-rates-market-has-baked-them-in-61330250 The trigger for actually needing to implement negative rates would be a continued sluggish economy. Covid impacts and Brexit impacts could slow the economy. I am leaning to a NO because i believe the BOE belkeves by summer 21 a global recovery will begin. https://www.bbc.com/news/business-54817872
I assess the odds at the same as a Black Swan. I forsee UK GDP down 5 percent due to Covid and epidemic,will it be 10 percent,like a depression. Could be. Will Johnson be kicked out Higher number
It’s not out of the question and other countries have used negative interest rates, but I think there is a lot of resistance to the idea, so I give it only 5%.

The markets seem to be pricing it in and the markets are pretty efficient. Something like this could happen w/ a nasty Brexit w/ no deal being the trigger event. But at the same time, this would be unprecedented for the UK so a no-deal Brexit may not be enough to cause them to resort to negative rates.

Interesting question. Bank rate is 0.1% at the moment after they lowered it from 0.75% in March. Usually they seem to change it by 0.25% when they do change it. I deem it likely the Brexit negotiations won't reach an agreement before the new year which likely be another hit to an already weakened economy. The only stimulus Bank of England can use, to my knowledge, is the Bank Rate. So a slam dunk yes? No, I'm not so sure they really want to go below zero. While it as to some extent worked in other countries it is not a normal state of economic affairs and there is a risk of confidence crisis I they do it I think. While only the investigation into the possibility of setting a negative interest rate can have negative impact, it also shows the markets Bank of England still has some tools left in the tool box which inspires some confidence.
